facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 677 of 1963 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 677 of 1963. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated March 31, 1961 of Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 283 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated March 31, 1961 of the Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 283 of 1959.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on March 25, 1964 by AYYANGAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: March 25, 1964. The judgment of the Court was delivered by AYYANGAR, J.- A very short question

facts.text: Respondent recruited as Upper Division Clerk by Government of Bombay in 1931.

anchor.surface_text: The facts giving rise to this appeal which are necessary to be narrated to appreciate the only point urged before us were these The respondent was recruited as an Upper Division Clerk

facts.text: Respondent appointed substantively as Junior Assistant in Political Department.

anchor.surface_text: by the Government of Bombay in 1931 and was later appointed substantively as a Junior Assistant in the Political Department.

facts.text: On September 17, 1943, respondent's services transferred on deputation to office of Controller of Rationing, Bombay as Senior Assistant in Rationing department.

anchor.surface_text: While so, on September 17, 1943 his services were transferred on deputation to the office of the Controller of Rationing, Bombay to work as a Senior Assistant in the newly started Rationing department which was a temporary department.

facts.text: By March 1954, respondent drawing pay of Rs. 460/- p.m. in grade Rs. 350-30-650 as Rationing Officer.

anchor.surface_text: He obtained successive promotions in this department and by March, 1954 he was drawing a pay of Rs. 460/- p.m. in the grade Rs. 350-30-650 as Rationing Officer.

facts.text: Rationing department abolished in March 1954.

anchor.surface_text: That department was abolished in March, 1954 and thereafter he was reverted to his parent department.

facts.text: Respondent reverted to parent department (Political Department), posted to Labour Department then Public Works Department.

anchor.surface_text: and thereafter he was reverted to his parent department. Though his parent department was the Political Department, the respondent was, after he ceased to be a Rationing Officer, posted first to the Labour Department and then to the Public Works Department.

facts.text: On reversion, respondent's pay fixed at Rs. 120/- p.m.

anchor.surface_text: When this reversion took place his pay was fixed at Rs. 120/- p.m.

facts.text: Respondent protested reversion and pay fixation.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent protested against this reversion and this loss of his emoluments on the ground that this fixation of pay was contrary to the Rules

facts.text: States Reorganisation Act, 1956 came into force, respondent allotted to State of Mysore.

anchor.surface_text: therefore, however, final orders were passed on his representation by the Government of Bombay, the States Reorganisation Act, 1956 came into force and the respondent was allotted to the State of Mysore.

facts.text: On November 27, 1958, Government of Mysore informed respondent he held post of Senior Assistant on June 1, 1954 on salary Rs. 225/- in grade Rs. 210-15-300.

anchor.surface_text: On November 27, 1958 the Government of Mysore informed the respondent through an official memorandum that in view of certain communications received by that Government from the Government of Bombay in answer to his representations he should be considered to have held the post of Senior Assistant on June 1, 1954 on a salary of Rs. 225/- in the grade Rs. 210-15-300.

facts.text: Respondent claimed entitled to be posted as Assistant Secretary on reversion.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent's complaint,however, was that even this order was in violation of the conditions of his service and he claimed that when he was reverted to the parent department he was entitled to be posted as an Assistant Secretary

facts.text: No dispute that respondent would have held post of Assistant Secretary as person next below him, Nadkarni, held that post.

anchor.surface_text: There was no dispute that subject to an argument to which we shall refer presently, the respondent would have held the post of Assistant Secretary because the person next below him-one Nadkarni-actually held that post on that day.

facts.text: Respondent filed writ petition under Art. 226 for mandamus to fix him in grade-pay of Assistant Secretary above Nadkarni.

anchor.surface_text: As the Government of Mysore refused to accede to his demand the respondent filed a petition under Art. 226 for inter alia a writ of mandamus directing the appellant-State to include the petitioner in the grade-pay of an Assistant Secretary I and fix him above Nadkarni.

facts.text: Appellant raised preliminary objection that complaint not justiciable based on circular dated October 31, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant raised a preliminary objection to the writ petition, the objection being that the complaint of the petitioner was not justiciable. This was primarily based upon the fact that the respondent relied upon a circular of the Government of Bombay dated October 31, 1950

facts.text: Full Bench opined circular gives effect to Rule 50b of Bombay Civil Services Rules.

anchor.surface_text: Before the learned Judges of the Full Bench the learned Advocate-General, however, brought to the notice of the Court that this circular merely gave effect to a statutory rule framed by the Government of Bombay. The relevant rule in this respect was rule 50 b

facts.text: Division Bench allowed writ and granted relief to respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges answered this question in the affirmative and thereafter the Division Bench which heard the petition allowed the writ and granted the respondent the relief that he sought.

facts.text: Respondent retired on superannuation by date of High Court proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: It might be mentioned that even by the date of the pendency of these proceedings in the High Court the respondent had retired on account of superannuation

facts.text: High Court granted certificate under Art. 133 for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant-State applied to the High Court for a certificate to enable an appeal to be filed to this Court and on this having been granted the appeal is now before us.

facts.text: Officer next below respondent in parent department, Nadkarni, appointed Assistant Secretary.

anchor.surface_text: He also pointed out that the officer next below him in his parent department had been appointed as an Assistant Secretary by virtue of normal and regular promotion.
under Art. 133 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: rule 50 b  of the Bombay Civil Services Rules which ran

50 b  Service in another post, other than a post carrying less pay referred to in clause  a  of rule 22 whether in a substantive or officiating capacity, service on deputation and leave other than extraordinary leave counts for increments in the time scale applicable to the post on which the Government servant holds a lien as well as in time scale applicable to the post or posts, if any, on which he would hold a lien had his lien not been suspended Provided that Government may, in any case in which they are satisfied that the leave was taken on account of illness or for any other cause beyond the Government servants control, direct that extraordinary leave shall be counted for increment under this clause.

arguments.claim: Rule 50b entitles reverted deputationist to increments and time scale of posts he would hold had lien not suspended, including promotions; circular gives effect.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this contention. In the first place, it is not clear whether the case of the respondent was one where he held a lien or one where the lien was suspended... By the use of the plural, it is clear that the rule contemplated... promotion... circular... gives proper effect to the provisions of Rule 50 b

arguments.claim: Service on deputation equated to parent department service for seniority-cum-merit promotions under next below rule; entitled to paper promotion if next below promoted.

anchor.surface_text: We see no force in this contention either... The service of an officer on deputation in another department is treated by the rule as equivalent to service in the parent department... What is indicated here is precisely what is termed... the next below rule under which an officer on deputation is given a paper-promotion

arguments.claim: Breach of statutory service rules under Art. 309/313 gives cause of action enforceable by court.

anchor.surface_text: in view of the decisions of this Court of which it is sufficient to refer to State of U.P. v. Babu Ram Upadhya it was not disputed that if there was a breach of a statutory rule framed under Art. 309 or which was continued under Art. 313

holdings.text: If there was a breach of a statutory rule framed under Art. 309 or which was continued under Art. 313 in relation to the conditions of service the aggrieved Government servant could have recourse to the Court for redress.

anchor.surface_text: in view of the decisions of this Court of which it is sufficient to refer to State of U.P. v. Babu Ram Upadhya 1  it was number disputed that if there was a breach of a statutory rule framed under Art. 309 or which was continued under Art. 313 in relation to the companyditions of service the aggrieved Government servant companyld have recourse to the Court for redress.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Undisputed in light of Supreme Court precedents such as State of U.P. v. Babu Ram Upadhya.

holdings.text: On a proper construction of Rule 50 b, an officer reverted from deputation is entitled to increments in the time scale applicable to the post on which he holds a lien as well as in time scale applicable to the post or posts on which he would hold a lien had his lien not been suspended, which contemplates promotion to higher posts during deputation.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this companytention. In the first place, it is number clear whether the case of the respondent was one where he held a lien or one where the lien was suspended, and numbermaterial was placed before the Court in this regard, the point in this form number being urged in the High companyrt. But even assuming that it was a case where the respondent had a lien and his lien had number been suspended it is difficult to see what logic there companyld be in interpreting the rule as providing different criteria in the two cases. Where the lien is suspended the rule speaks of the post or posts, if any he would have held if his lien had number been -suspended. By the use of the plural, it is clear that the rule ,contemplated the suspended lien being transferred from one post to another-in other words, to a promotion from one post to another during the period of the service in another ,department. If there was any ambiguity in what the rule meant it is wholly dispelled by reference to the circular which ensures to the officer on deputation in another department that he shall be restored to the position he would have occupied in his parent department had he number been deputed. It was number suggested that there was any ambiguity in the wording of this circular which, in our opinion, gives proper effect to the provisions of Rule 50 b

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of plural 'post or posts'; uniform logic whether lien held or suspended; circular dated October 31, 1950 dispels ambiguity by restoring position as if not deputed.

holdings.text: The circular dated October 31, 1950 gives proper effect to the provisions of Rule 50 b.

anchor.surface_text: It was number suggested that there was any ambiguity in the wording of this circular which, in our opinion, gives proper effect to the provisions of Rule 50 b   1  1961 2 S.C.R. 679.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Circular ensures restoration to position as if not deputed, aligning with Rule 50b's intent.

holdings.text: A Government servant on deputation has a legal right to be promoted (via paper promotion) to a higher post in the parent department under the next below rule where the promotion is on seniority-cum-merit basis and the officer next below him is promoted.

anchor.surface_text: We see numberforce in this companytention either. Learned Counsel is right only in so far as the promotion involved relates to a selection post. But where it is based on seniority-cum-merit, those companysiderations are number relevant. The service of an officer on deputation in another department is treated by the rule as equivalent to service in the parent department and it is this equation between the services in the two departments that forms the basis of Rule 50 b . So long therefore as the service of the employee in the new department is satisfactory and he is obtaining the increments and promotions in that department, it stands to reason that that satisfactory service and the manner of its discharge in the post he actually fills, should be deemed to be rendered in the parent department also so as to entitle him to promotions, which are often on seniority-cummerit basis. What is indicated here is precisely what is termed in official language the next below rule under which an officer on deputation is given a paper-promotion and shown as holding a higher post in the parent department if the officer next below him there is being promoted. If there are adverse remarks against him in the new department or punishments inflicted on him there, different companysiderations would arise and these adverse remarks etc. would and companyld certainly be taken into account in the parent department also, but that is number the position here.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deputation service equated to parent department service under Rule 50b; for seniority-cum-merit promotions, satisfactory service entitles to next below rule paper promotion; distinguished from selection posts.

holdings.text: The respondent was entitled to be posted as an Assistant Secretary with emoluments of that post on reversion, as he would have held that post had he not been on deputation, with Nadkarni (next below) holding it.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners companyplaint,however, was that even this order was in violation of the companyditions of his service and he claimed that when he was reverted to the parent department he was entitled to be posted as an Assistant Secretary-a post which according to him, he would have held on that date had he number been deputed to the department of Civil Supplies on September 17, 1943. There was numberdispute that subject to an argument to which we shall refer presently, the respondent would have held the post of Assistant Secretary because the person next below him-one Nadkarni-actually held that post on that day.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of Rule 50b construction and next below rule to undisputed facts; arguments against rejected.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this companytention. In the first place, it is number clear whether the case of the respondent was one where he held a lien or one where the lien was suspended, and numbermaterial was placed before the Court in this regard, the point in this form number being urged in the High companyrt. But even assuming that it was a case where the respondent had a lien and his lien had number been suspended it is difficult to see what logic there companyld be in interpreting the rule as providing different criteria in the two cases. Where the lien is suspended the rule speaks of the post or posts, if any he would have held if his lien had number been -suspended. By the use of the plural, it is clear that the rule ,contemplated the suspended lien being transferred from one post to another-in other words, to a promotion from one post to another during the period of the service in another ,department. If there was any ambiguity in what the rule meant it is wholly dispelled by reference to the circular which ensures to the officer on deputation in another department that he shall be restored to the position he would have occupied in his parent department had he number been deputed. It was number suggested that there was any ambiguity in the wording of this circular which, in our opinion, gives proper effect to the provisions of Rule 50 b

edges.explanation: Holding of legal right to promotion under next below rule addresses the issue

anchor.surface_text: We see numberforce in this companytention either. Learned Counsel is right only in so far as the promotion involved relates to a selection post. But where it is based on seniority-cum-merit, those companysiderations are number relevant. The service of an officer on deputation in another department is treated by the rule as equivalent to service in the parent department and it is this equation between the services in the two departments that forms the basis of Rule 50 b . So long therefore as the service of the employee in the new department is satisfactory and he is obtaining the increments and promotions in that department, it stands to reason that that satisfactory service and the manner of its discharge in the post he actually fills, should be deemed to be rendered in the parent department also so as to entitle him to promotions, which are often on seniority-cummerit basis. What is indicated here is precisely what is termed in official language the next below rule under which an officer on deputation is given a paper-promotion and shown as holding a higher post in the parent department if the officer next below him there is being promoted. If there are adverse remarks against him in the new department or punishments inflicted on him there, different companysiderations would arise and these adverse remarks etc. would and companyld certainly be taken into account in the parent department also, but that is number the position here.
